{{distinguish|voltage clamp}} {{Refimprove|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} [[File:Positive Voltage Clamping V2.svg|frame|Positive unbiased voltage clamping vertically translates the input waveform so that all parts of it are approximately greater than 0 V. Note that the negative swing of the output will not dip below about −0.6 V, assuming a silicon pn diode.<ref name="Jones1995">{{cite book|author=Martin Hartley Jones|title=A Practical Introduction to Electronic Circuits|year=1995|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-47879-3|page=261}}</ref>]] A '''clamper''' is an [[electronic circuit]] that fixes either the positive or the negative peak excursions of a signal to a defined value by shifting its DC value<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/953450203|title=Practical electrical engineering|last=Makarov|first=Sergey N.|last2=Ludwig|first2=Reinhold|last3=Bitar|first3=Stephen J.|publisher=Springer International|others=|year=|isbn=9783319211732|location=Switzerland|pages=827|oclc=953450203}}</ref>. The clamper does not restrict the peak-to-peak excursion of the signal, it moves the whole signal up or down so as to place the peaks at the reference level. A '''diode clamp''' (a simple, common type) consists of a [[diode]], which conducts electric current in only one direction and prevents the signal exceeding the reference value; and a [[capacitor]], which provides a DC offset from the stored charge. The capacitor forms a [[time constant]] with the [[resistor]] load, which determines the range of frequencies over which the clamper will be effective.
==General function== A clamping circuit (also known as a clamper) will bind the upper or lower extreme of a waveform to a fixed DC voltage level. These circuits are also known as DC voltage restorers. Clampers can be constructed in both positive and negative polarities. When unbiased, clamping circuits will fix the voltage lower limit (or upper limit, in the case of negative clampers) to 0 volts. These circuits clamp a peak of a waveform to a specific DC level compared with a capacitively-coupled signal, which swings about its average DC level.
The clamping network is one that will "clamp" a signal to a different dc level. The network must have a capacitor, a diode, and a resistive element, but it can also employ an independent dc supply to introduce an additional shift. The magnitude of R and C must be chosen such that the time constant RC is large enough to ensure that the voltage across the capacitor does not discharge significantly during the interval the diode is nonconducting.
==Types== Clamp circuits are categorised by their operation; negative or positive, and biased or unbiased. A positive clamp circuit(negative peak clamper) outputs a purely positive waveform from an input signal; it offsets the input signal so that all of the waveform is greater than 0 V. A negative clamp is the opposite of this—this clamp outputs a purely negative waveform from an input signal. A bias voltage between the diode and ground offsets the output voltage by that amount.
For example, an input signal of peak value 5 V (V<sub>INpeak</sub> = 5 V) is applied to a positive clamp with a bias of 3 V (V<sub>BIAS</sub> = 3 V), the peak output voltage will be:
:V<sub>OUTpeak</sub> = 2 × V<sub>INpeak</sub> + V<sub>BIAS</sub> :V<sub>OUTpeak</sub> = 2 × 5 V + 3 V :V<sub>OUTpeak</sub> = 13 V
Note that the peak to peak excursion remains at 2{{nbsp}}V
===Positive unbiased=== [[File:Positive Voltage Clamping Circuit (simulated).svg|300px|thumb|A positive unbiased clamp.]] In the negative cycle of the input AC signal, the diode is forward biased and conducts, charging the capacitor to the peak negative value of V<sub>IN</sub>. During the positive cycle, the diode is reverse biased and thus does not conduct. The output voltage is therefore equal to the voltage stored in the capacitor plus the input voltage<ref>{{cite book |last1=Horowitz |first1=Paul |last2=Winfield |first2=Hill |title=The Art of Electronics Third Edition |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=New York |isbn=9780521809269 |page=37}}</ref>, so V<sub>OUT</sub> = V<sub>IN</sub> + V<sub>INpeak</sub>. This is also called a [[Villard circuit]]. {{Clear}}
===Negative unbiased=== [[File:Negative Voltage Clamping Circuit (simulated).svg|300px|thumb|A negative unbiased clamp]] A negative unbiased clamp is the opposite of the equivalent positive clamp. In the positive cycle of the input AC signal, the diode is forward biased and conducts, charging the capacitor to the peak positive value of V<sub>IN</sub>. During the negative cycle, the diode is reverse biased and thus does not conduct. The output voltage is therefore equal to the voltage stored in the capacitor plus the input voltage again, so V<sub>OUT</sub> = V<sub>IN</sub> − V<sub>INpeak</sub>. {{Clear}}
===Positive biased=== [[File:Positive Biased Voltage Clamping Circuit (simulated).svg|300px|thumb|A positive biased clamp]] A positive biased voltage clamp is identical to an equivalent unbiased clamp but with the output voltage offset by the bias amount V<sub>BIAS</sub>. Thus, V<sub>OUT</sub> = V<sub>IN</sub> + (V<sub>INpeak</sub> + V<sub>BIAS</sub>). {{Clear}}
===Negative biased=== [[File:Negative Biased Voltage Clamping Circuit (simulated).svg|300px|thumb|A negative biased clamp]] A negative biased voltage clamp is likewise identical to an equivalent unbiased clamp but with the output voltage offset in the negative direction by the bias amount V<sub>BIAS</sub>. Thus, V<sub>OUT</sub> = V<sub>IN</sub> − (V<sub>INpeak</sub> + V<sub>BIAS</sub>). {{Clear}}
===Op-amp circuit=== [[File:Precision op-amp clamp.svg|thumb|Precision op-amp clamp circuit<ref>S. P. Bali, ''Linear Integrated Circuits'', p.279, Tata McGraw-Hill, 2008 {{ISBN|0-07-064807-7}}.</ref>]] The figure shows an op-amp clamp circuit with a non-zero reference clamping voltage. The advantage here is that the clamping level is at precisely the reference voltage. There is no need to take into account the forward volt drop of the diode (which is necessary in the preceding simple circuits as this adds to the reference voltage). The effect of the diode volt drop on the circuit output will be divided down by the gain of the amplifier, resulting in an insignificant error. The circuit also has a great improvement in linearity at small input signals in comparison to the simple diode circuit and is largely unaffected by changes in the load.
==Clamping for input protection== Clamping can be used to adapt an input signal to a device that cannot make use of or may be damaged by the signal range of the original input.
==Principles of operation== During the first negative phase of the AC input voltage, the capacitor in a positive clamper circuit charges rapidly. As ''V''<sub>in</sub> becomes positive, the capacitor serves as a voltage doubler; since it has stored the equivalent of ''V''<sub>in</sub> during the negative cycle, it provides nearly that voltage during the positive cycle. This essentially doubles the voltage seen by the load. As ''V''<sub>in</sub> becomes negative, the capacitor acts as a battery of the same voltage of ''V''<sub>in</sub>. The voltage source and the capacitor counteract each other, resulting in a net voltage of zero as seen by the load.
===Loading=== For passive type clampers with a capacitor, followed by a diode in parallel with the load, the load can significantly affect perfomance. The magnitude of ''R'' and ''C'' are chosen so that the time constant, <math>\tau = RC </math>, is large enough to ensure that the voltage across the capacitor does not discharge significantly during the diode's non-conducting interval. A load resistance that is too low (heavy load) will partially discharge the capacitor and cause the waveform peaks to drift off the intended clamp voltage. This effect is greatest at low frequecies. At a higher frequency, there is less time between cycles for the capacitor to discharge.
The capacitor cannot be made arbitrarily large to overcome load discharge. During the conducting interval, the capacitor must be recharged. The time taken to do this is governed by a different time constant, this time set by the capacitance and the internal impedance of the driving circuit. Since the peak voltage is reached in one quarter cycle and then starts to fall again, the capacitor must be recharged in a quarter cycle. This requirement calls for a low value of capacitance.
The two conflicting requirements for capacitance value may be irreconcilable in applications with a high driving impedance and low load impedance. In such cases, an active circuit must be used such as the op-amp circuit described above.
==Biased versus non-biased== By using a voltage source and resistor, the clamper can be biased to bind the output voltage to a different value. The voltage supplied to the potentiometer will be equal to the offset from zero (assuming an ideal diode) in the case of either a positive or negative clamper (the clamper type will determine the direction of the offset). If a negative voltage is supplied to either positive or negative, the waveform will cross the x-axis and be bound to a value of this magnitude on the opposite side. Zener diodes can also be used in place of a voltage source and potentiometer, hence setting the offset at the Zener voltage.
==Examples==
Clamping circuits were common in [[analog television]] receivers. These sets have a DC restorer circuit, which returns the voltage of the video signal during the 'back porch' of the line blanking (retrace) period to 0 V. Low frequency interference, especially power line hum, induced onto the signal spoils the rendering of the image, and in extreme cases causes the set to lose [[analog television#Synchronization|synchronization]]. This interference can be effectively removed via this method.
==See also== *[[Clipper (electronics)]] *[[Schottky diode]]

Marston|title=Diode, Transistor & Fet Circuits Manual|year=1991|publisher=Newness|isbn=978-1-4831-3540-3|pages=13–17}} * {{cite book|author=|title=Rectifier Applications Handbook HB214/D Rev. 2|publisher=[[ON Semiconductor]]|date=Nov 2001|pages=160–161}} * {{cite book|author=J. A. Coekin|title=High-Speed Pulse Techniques|year=1975|publisher=Pergamon|isbn=978-1-4831-0548-2|pages=60–64}}

{{Coord|37|23|11.76|N|122|1|54.07|W|scale:1563_region:US|display=title}} {{Infobox company | name = Clover Network, Inc. | owner = [[First Data]] | logo = Clover Network Logo.png | image = Clover Station with receipt printer and cash drawer.jpg | image_caption = The touchscreen Clover Station with a receipt printer and cash drawer. | type = [[Private company|Private]] | foundation = | founder = Leonard Speiser, John Beatty | area_served = [[World]]wide | location_city = Sunnyvale, CA | location_country = [[United States]] | key_people = | revenue = | homepage = [http://www.clover.com clover.com] | screenshot = | caption = | num_employees = 200+ | registration = | founded = April 2012 | current_status = | industry = [[Point of sale|POS]] }}
'''Clover''' is a cloud-based Android point of sale ([[Point of sale|POS]]) platform that was launched in April 2012. The company is headquartered in [[Sunnyvale, CA]]. Clover was acquired on December 28, 2012 by [[First Data|First Data Corporation]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/10/09/first-data-quietly-buys-payments-startup-clover-launches-point-of-sale-platform-for-merchants/ | title=First Data Quietly Buys Payments Startup Clover; Launches Point of Sale Platform for Merchants}}</ref> Bank of America Merchant Services was the first to announce it would sell Clover to its merchant base in October 2013.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://merch.bankofamerica.com/cloverdetailspage | title=POS Device Solutions for Small Business}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.firstdata.com/en_us/about-first-data/media/press-releases/10_09_13.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20140426215505/https://www.firstdata.com/en_us/about-first-data/media/press-releases/10_09_13.html |archivedate=2014-04-26 |df= }}</ref> PNC Merchant Services was the second to announce it would sell Clover to its merchant base.<ref>https://www.pnc.com/webapp/unsec/Blank.do?siteArea=/pnccorp/PNC/Home/Small+Business/Merchant+Services/Accept+Payments/Merchant+Services+Clover</ref>
==History==
===Funding & early history=== Clover was incorporated in October 15, 2010 and raised $5.5M on November 1, 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1517885/000151788511000001/xslFormDX01/primary_doc.xml | title=Sec Form D}}</ref> The lead investor was [[Sutter Hill Ventures]] with participation from [[Andreessen Horowitz]] and a number of angel investors. The company was founded by John Beatty, Leonard Speiser, and Kelvin Zheng. The company secured an additional $3M convertible note from Sutter Hill Ventures in April 2012.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1517885/000151788512000001/xslFormDX01/primary_doc.xml | title=Sec Form D}}</ref>
=== First hardware product === Clover launched its first hardware solution, the Clover Station, in 2013 and began shipping it in January 2014.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://gigaom.com/2013/10/09/after-a-quiet-year-clover-emerges-with-a-sexy-cash-register-a-new-owner/ | title=After a quiet year, Clover emerges with a sexy cash register & a new owner| date=2013-10-09}}</ref> Clover opened its App Marketplace to third party developers in 2014. [[First Data#Gyft|Gyft]] announced the launch of its Gift Cloud Service on Clover in April 2014.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.digitaljournal.com/pr/1837151 | title=Gyft Announces Launch of First Cloud-based Mobile Gift Card Solution for Small to Mid-Sized Businesses - Press Release - Digital Journal}}</ref>
First Data announced the sale of 17,000 Clover Stations six months after the release of the product.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-09-16/kkr-banks-on-bisignano-forging-apple-deal-at-first-data.html | title=Bloomberg - Are you a robot?}}</ref> This put Clover ahead of Square Stand in terms of total units shipped.
On September 9, 2014 Clover announced its work with Apple to support Apple Pay via its Android POS Platform.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://clover-developers.blogspot.com/2014/09/apple-pay.html | title=Clover Developers Blog: How Apple Pay works and why it matters for developers| date=2014-09-09}}</ref> Clover described the functionality in a blog post<ref>{{cite web | url=http://clover-developers.blogspot.com/2014/09/apple-pay.html | title=Clover Developers Blog: How Apple Pay works and why it matters for developers| date=2014-09-09}}</ref> that was featured on the home page of Hacker News.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://news.ycombinator.com/item?id=8292140 | title=How Apple Pay works and why it matters for developers | Hacker News}}</ref>
=== Second hardware product === Clover announced its second hardware product, the Clover Mobile, at the Money 20/20 conference in November 2014.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://techcrunch.com/2014/11/04/first-data-debuts-clover-mobile-a-wireless-tablet-based-point-of-sale/ | title=First Data Debuts Clover Mobile, A Wireless, Tablet-Based Point-Of-Sale}}</ref> On March 19, 2015, Clover Mobile won the Gold medal for the Best POS innovation at the PYMNTS.com Innovator Awards ceremony.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.firstdata.com/en_us/all-features/clover-mobile-wins-gold.html | title=All Small Business Payment Solutions | First Data}}</ref> Clover Mobile features a complete EMVCo compliant payments solution with an on-screen pin-pad,<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.clover.com/pos-hardware/mobile | title=Clover}}</ref> that is fully PCI PTS 4.0 compliant.<ref>https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/popups/pts_device.php?appnum=4-40156</ref> It also features an EMVCo compliant Contactless payment interface which enables it to support Apple Pay among other contactless payment modes. The device has an ergonomic handle with an integrated barcode scanner<ref> https://www.firstdata.com/downloads/marketing-merchant/FD_Solutions_with_Clover_Mobile.pdf</ref> - with an external wireless mobile printer accessory<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.clover.com/pos-hardware/accessories?accessoriesTypeGroup=mobile | title=Clover}}</ref> designed to keep the device lightweight and reduce fatigue.
=== Third hardware product === Clover's third hardware product, the Clover Mini was launched by First Data on June 16, 2015.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20150616006141/en/Data-Launches-Clover%C2%AE-Mini-Future-Payment-Terminals | title=First Data Launches Clover® Mini, the Future of Payment Terminals| date=2015-06-16}}</ref> Like Clover Mobile, Clover Mini<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.clover.com/pos-hardware/mini | title=Clover}}</ref> is a PCI PTS 4.0 approved,<ref> https://www.pcisecuritystandards.org/popups/pts_device.php?appnum=4-40158</ref> EMVCo compliant contact and contactless next generation payment device. Clover Mini has a built-in receipt printer and is designed to be a terminal replacement with the support for advanced payments interfaces, while also allowing Merchants to install apps from the Clover App Market.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.clover.com/appmarket/ | title=Clover}}</ref> Clover Mini also features an USB hub allowing easy interface of peripherals such as external barcode scanners, cash drawer <ref>https://www.firstdata.com/downloads/marketing-merchant/FD_Solutions_with_Clover_Mini.pdf</ref> and a Merchant keypad (for cases where the Mini is Customer-facing).<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.clover.com/pos-hardware/accessories?accessoriesTypeGroup=mini | title=Clover}}</ref>
==Acquisition== On December 28, 2012, Clover entered into a merger agreement with First Data Corporation.<ref> https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/740112/000104746913011139/a2217468zs-4.htm</ref> In a radio interview with Wharton professor Rahul Kapoor<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.innonavi.com/recent-guests/ | title=Recent Guests}}</ref> the structure of the acquisition was explained. An operating agreement was put into place whereby Clover would receive $100M in funding to run independently. First Data would be responsible for sales and support, while Clover built all new payment hardware/software for the company. The deal utilized a "Founder's Clause" that would trigger a very large penalty payment if the parent company interfered with operations of Clover. Thirty two months after the acquisition Clover was mentioned 88 times in the S-1 filed by First Data Corporation.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/883980/000119312515256975/d31022ds1.htm | title=Form S-1}}</ref>

'''Engineering psychology''', also known as Human Factors Engineering, is the science of [[human behavior]] and capability, applied to the design and operation of systems and technology.<ref name="Stanton" /> As an applied field of [[psychology]] and an interdisciplinary part of [[ergonomics]], it aims to improve the [[Human–machine system|relationships between people and machines]] by redesigning equipment, interactions, or the environment in which they take place. The work of an engineering psychologist is often described as making the relationship more "user-friendly."
== History == Engineering psychology was created from within [[experimental psychology]].<ref name="Grether"/> Engineering psychology started during World War I (1914).<ref name="Schultz & Schultz"/> The reason why this subject was developed during this time was because many of America’s weapons were failing; bombs not falling in the right place to weapons attacking normal marine life.<ref name="Grether"/> The fault was traced back to human errors.<ref name="Grether"/> One of the first designs to be built to restrain human error was the use of [[psychoacoustics]] by S.S. Stevens and L.L. Beranek were two of the first American psychologists called upon to help change how people and machinery worked together.<ref name="Grether"/> One of their first assignments was to try and reduce noise levels in military aircraft. The work was directed at improving intelligibility of military communication systems and appeared to have been very successful. However it was not until after August 1945 that levels of research in engineering psychology began to increase significantly.<ref name="Grether"/> This occurred because the research that started in 1940 now began to show.<ref name="Grether"/>
[[Lillian Gilbreth]] combined the talents of an [[engineer]], [[psychologist]] and mother of twelve. Her appreciation of [[human factor]]s made her successful in the implementation of [[time and motion]] studies and [[scientific management]]. She went on to pioneer [[ergonomic]]s in the kitchen, inventing the [[pedal bin]], for example.<ref>{{citation |title=A brief history of modern psychology |author=Ludy T. Benjamin |page=105 |chapter=Lillian Gilbreth's Engineering Psychology |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |year=2007 |isbn=978-1-4051-3205-3}}</ref>
In Britain, the two world wars generated much formal study of human factors which affected the efficiency of munitions output and warfare. In World War I, the Health of Munitions Workers Committee was created in 1915. This made recommendations based upon studies of the effects of overwork on efficiency which resulted in policies of providing breaks and limiting hours of work, including avoidance of work on Sunday. The [[Industrial Fatigue Research Board]] was created in 1918 to take this work forward.<ref>{{citation |title=Employers, the government, and industrial fatigue in Britain, 1890-1918 |first=A.J. |last=McIvor |journal=British Journal of Industrial Medicine |year=1987 |volume=44 |pages=724–732 |doi=10.1136/oem.44.11.724|pmc=1007909 }}</ref> In WW2, researchers at Cambridge University such as [[Frederic Bartlett]] and [[Kenneth Craik]] started work on the operation of equipment in 1939 and this resulted in the creation of the [[Unit for Research in Applied Psychology]] in 1944.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.mrc-cbu.cam.ac.uk/history/legacyconference/briefingnotes.html |title=Notes on the work of the Medical Research Council Applied Psychology Unit 1944-1997 |chapter=Formation of the APU |publisher=MRC Cognition and Brain Sciences Unit}}</ref>
== Related subjects == * [[Cognitive ergonomics]] & [[cognitive engineering]] - studies cognition in work settings, in order to optimize ''human well-being and system performance''. It is a subset of the larger field of [[human factors]] and [[ergonomics]]. * [[Applied psychology]] - The use of psychological principles to overcome problems in other domains. It has been argued that engineering psychology is separate from applied (cognitive) psychology because advances in cognitive psychology have infrequently informed engineering psychology research. Surprisingly, work in engineering psychology often seems to inform developments in cognitive psychology. For example, engineering psychology research has enabled cognitive psychologists to explain why [[GUI]]s seem easier to use than character-based computer interfaces (such as [[DOS]]).<ref name=Stanton>{{cite journal|last=Stanton|first=N.|title=Engineering Psychology: Another Science of Common Sense?|journal=The Psychologist|year=1996|volume=9|issue=7|pages=300–303|url=http://www.katiandgraham.com/eng_psy.htm|accessdate=2 July 2011}}</ref>
=== Engineering Psychology, Ergonomics, & Human Factors === Although the comparability of these terms and many others have been a topic of debate, the differences of these fields can be seen in the applications of the respective fields.
Engineering psychology is concerned with the adaptation of the equipment and environment to people, based upon their psychological capacities and limitations with the objective of improving overall system performance, involving human and machine elements<ref name="Stanton" /> Engineering psychologists strive to match equipment requirements with the capabilities of human operators by changing the design of the equipment.<ref name="Schultz & Schultz">{{Cite book| last = Schultz| first = D| authorlink = |author2=Schultz, E.| title = Psychology and work today | publisher = Pearson |location=New Jersey | year = 2010| url = | isbn = 978-0-205-68358-1 | doi = | accessdate = }}</ref> An example of this matching was the redesign of the mailbags used by letter carriers. Engineering psychologists discovered that mailbag with a waist-support strap, and a double bag that requires the use of both shoulders, reduces muscle fatigue.<ref name="Schultz & Schultz" /> Another example involves the cumulative trauma disorders grocery checkout workers suffered as the result of repetitive wrist movements using electronic scanners. Engineering psychologists found that the optimal checkout station design would allow for workers to easily use either hand to distribute the workload between both wrists.<ref name="Schultz & Schultz" />
The field of [[ergonomics]] is based on scientific studies of ordinary people in work situations and is applied to the design of processes and machines, to the layout of work places, to methods of work, and to the control of the physical environment, in order to achieve greater efficiency of both men and machines<ref name="Human Factors">{{Cite web| last = Licht, | first = D| authorlink = |author2=D. Polzella |author3=K. Boff| title =Human factors, ergonomics, and human factors engineering: An analysis of deinitions| work = | publisher =| url = http://www.hfes.org/Web/EducationalResources/HFDefinitions.pdf| format = | doi = | accessdate= }}</ref> An example of an ergonomics study is the evaluation of the effects of screwdriver handle shape, surface material and workpiece orientation on torque performance, finger force distribution and muscle activity in a maximum screwdriving torque task.<ref name="Kong">{{Cite journal| last = Kong| first = Y. K.| authorlink = |author2=Lowe, B. D. |author3=Lee, S. J. |author4=Krieg, E. F. | title = Evaluation of handle design characteristics in a maximum screwdriving torque task| journal = Ergonomics |volume=50 |issue=9 |pages=1404–1418| publisher =| year = 2007| url = | format = | doi = 10.1080/00140130701393775}}</ref> Another example of an ergonomics study is the effects of shoe traction and obstacle height on friction.<ref name="James">{{Citation| last1= James| first1= Jeremy| authorlink = | author2=Houser |author3=Leslie |author4=Decker |first5=Nicholas |last5=Stergioub| title = Steppin over the obstacles of different heights and varued shoe traction alter the kinetic strategy and leading limb.| page=1847| publisher =| year = 2008| url = | format = | doi = }}</ref> Similarly, many topics in ergonomics deal with the actual science of matching man to equipment and encompasses narrower fields such as Engineering Psychology.
At one point in time, the term [[human factors]] was used in place of ergonomics in Europe.<ref name="Grether">{{Cite journal | last = Grether| first = F| authorlink = | title = Engineering psychology in the United States| journal = American Psychologist |volume=23 |issue=10 |pages=743–751| publisher = | year = 1962| url = | format = | doi = 10.1037/h0026850 }}</ref> Human factors involve interdisciplinary scientific research and studies to seek to realize greater recognition and understanding of the worker's characteristics, needs, abilities, and limitations when the procedures and products of technology are being designed.<ref name="Human Factors" /> This field utilizes knowledge from several fields such as mechanical engineering, psychology, and industrial engineering<ref name="Human Factors" /> to design instruments.
[[Human factors]] is broader than engineering psychology, which is focused specifically on designing systems that accommodate the information-processing capabilities of the brain.<ref>Wickens, C. and Hollands, J. (1999), ''Engineering Psychology and Human Performance'', Prentice Hall, {{ISBN|0-321-04711-7}}</ref>
Although the work in the respective fields differ, there are some similarities between these. These fields share the same objectives which are to optimize the effectiveness and efficiency with which human activities are conducted as well as to improve the general quality of life through increased safety, reduced fatigue and stress, increased comfort, and satisfaction.<ref name="Stanton" />
===Importance of Engineering Psychologists===
Engineering psychologists contribute to the design of a variety of products, including dental and surgical tools, cameras, toothbrushes and car-seats. They have been involved in the re-design of the mailbags used by letter carriers. More than 20% of letter carriers suffer from [[musculoskeletal injury]] such as lower back pain from carrying mailbags slung over their shoulders. A mailbag with a waist-support strap, and a double bag that requires the use of both shoulders, has been shown to reduce muscle fatigue.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
Research by engineering psychologists has demonstrated that using cell-phones while driving degrades performance by increasing driver reaction time, particularly among older drivers, and can lead to higher accident risk among drivers of all ages. Research findings such as these have supported governmental regulation of cell-phone use.<ref>{{cite book|last=Schultz|first=Duane P. Schultz, Sydney Ellen|title=Psychology and work today : an introduction to industrial and organizational psychology|year=2010|publisher=Prentice Hall|location=Upper Saddle River, N.J.|isbn=978-0205683581|page=384|edition=10th}}</ref>

Roscoe |year=1997 |title=The Adolescence of Engineering Psychology |publisher=Human Factors and Ergonomics Society |url=http://www.hfes.org/Web/PubPages/adolescencehtml.html}} *{{citation |title=The Corsini Encyclopedia of Psychology |chapter=Engineering Psychology |author=Francis Durso, Patricia DeLucia |pages=573–576 |volume=2 |publisher=John Wiley and Sons |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-470-17026-7}} *{{citation |first1=Christopher D. |last1=Wickens |first2=J.G. |last2=Hollands |title=Engineering Psychology and Human Performance |publisher=Prentice-Hall |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-321-04711-3}} * Journal of Engineering Psychology<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/title/journal-of-engineering-psychology/oclc/1607948/editions?referer=di&editionsView=true]</ref> * {{cite book|last=Howell|first=William Carl|title=Engineering Psychology: Current Perspectives in Research |year=1971 |publisher=Appleton-Century-Crofts |location=New York|isbn=978-0-390-46456-9}} * {{cite book|last=Wickens|first=Christopher D.|title=Engineering Psychology and Human Performance |year=1984 |publisher=Merrill |location=Columbus}}

{{Infobox company | name = | logo = Thermo Fisher Scientific logo.svg | type = [[Public company|Public]] ({{NYSE|TMO}}) | location = [[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham, Massachusetts, USA]] | key_people = Marc N. Casper (President & [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) | homepage = [http://www.thermofisher.com/ www.thermofisher.com] }}
'''Fermentas''' was a biotechnology company specializing in the discovery and production of [[molecular biology]] products for [[life science]] research and diagnostics. Since 2010, Fermentas has been part of [[Thermo Fisher Scientific]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.genengnews.com/gen-news-highlights/thermo-fisher-scientific-to-purchase-fermentas-for-260m/81243466|title=Thermo Fisher Scientific to Purchase Fermentas for $260M|date=27 May 2010|publisher=Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology News}}</ref>
==Corporate profile==
In 2003, Fermentas consolidated its international business and set up a controlling enterprise, Fermentas International in Canada. Fermentas International became the shareholder of Fermentas in [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]], and its joint ventures in the United States, Canada and Germany (as well as Fermentas China established in 2009).
In 2010, Fermentas International was acquired by [[Thermo Fisher Scientific]]. Fermentas, and all of its enterprises, became part of the Analytical Technology segment of the Thermo Fisher.<ref>http://ir.thermofisher.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=89145&p=irol-newsArticle&ID=1431892&highlight=</ref>
Fermentas has principal manufacturing operations in [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]].
==Products==
Fermentas is a producer of molecular biology products and is known for its restriction enzymes and DNA ladders and molecular weight markers.
Main products are FastDigest and conventional [[restriction enzymes]], [[DNA]]/[[RNA]] modifying enzymes, transfection [[reagents]], [[nucleotides]] and primers, products for [[PCR]] and [[RT-PCR]], molecular cloning, nucleic acid purification, in vitro transcription, molecular labeling and detection, DNA, RNA, [[protein]] electrophoresis.
All Fermentas’ products are produced in Class D [[clean-room]] facilities, qualified and certified as per [[European Union|EU]] directives and [[International Society for Pharmaceutical Engineering|ISPE]] guidelines, which are prerequisite for [[Good Manufacturing Practice|GMP]] manufacturing. The company is operating under [[ISO 9001|ISO9001]], [[ISO13485]] quality and [[ISO 14000|ISO14001]] environmental management systems.

{{Infobox scientist | bgcolour = | name = Fernanda Viégas | image =FernandaViegasJI1.jpg | image_size = | caption = | birthname =Fernanda Bertini Viégas | birthdate = 1971 | field = [[Information visualization|visualization]], [[design]], [[interactive art]], [[journalism]] | work_institution = [[Thomas J. Watson Research Center|IBM Research]]
[[Google]] | alma_mater = Ph.D. Media Arts & Sciences, [[MIT Media Laboratory]] | known_for = [[History Flow]], [[Many Eyes]], Chat Circles | residence = Cambridge, Massachusetts | deathdate = | deathplace = | nationality = [[Brazil]]ian | awards = }} '''Fernanda Bertini Viégas''' (born 1971) is a [[Brazil]]ian scientist and designer, whose work focuses on the social, collaborative and artistic aspects of information visualization. == Biography == Viégas received a Ph.D. in Media Arts and Sciences from the [[MIT Media Lab]] in 2005. The same year she began work at the [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]], Massachusetts location of IBM's [[Thomas J. Watson Research Center]] as part of the Visual Communication Lab. In April 2010, she and [[Martin M. Wattenberg]] started a new venture called Flowing Media, Inc., to focus on visualization aimed at consumers and mass audiences.{{cite web|url=http://hint.fm/blog/2010/04/08/a-new-chapter/ |title=A New Chapter — Visual Hint |publisher=Hint.fm |date= |accessdate=2010-09-04}} Four months later, both of them joined Google as the co-leaders of the Google's "Big Picture" data visualization group in Cambridge, Massachusetts.{{cite web|url=http://hint.fm/blog/2010/08/05/that-was-fast/ |title=That was fast! — Visual Hint |publisher=Hint.fm |date= |accessdate=2010-09-04}}{{cite web|url=http://fernandaviegas.com/bio.html |title=Fernanda B. Viégas |publisher=Fernandaviegas.com |date=2008-08-31 |accessdate=2010-09-04}} == Work == === Social visualization === Viégas began her research while at the [[MIT Media Lab]], focusing on [[graphical interface]]s for [[online communication]]. Her Chat Circles system introduced ideas such as [[proximity-based filtering]] of conversation and a visual archive of chat history displaying the overall rhythm and form of a conversation.''Chat Circles''. Fernanda B. Viégas and Judith Donath. ACM Conference on Computer-Human Interaction (CHI), 1999 Her [[email]] visualization designs (including PostHistory and Themail) are the foundation for many other systems; her findings on how visualizations are often used for storytelling influenced subsequent work on the collaborative aspects of visualization.Baby Names, Visualization, and Social Data Analysis Martin Wattenberg. InfoVis 2005 While at MIT, she also studied usage of [[Usenet]] and [[blog]]s.Jeffrey Rosen, [https://www.nytimes.com/2004/12/19/magazine/19PHENOM.html Your Blog or Mine?], ''New York Times Magazine'', December 19, 2004 === Collective intelligence and public visualization === [[File:Viegas-UserActivityonWikipedia.gif|thumb|Fernanda Viégas, "Chromogram," 2006]] A second stream of work, in partnership with [[Martin M. Wattenberg|Martin Wattenberg]], centers on collective intelligence and the public use of data visualization. Her work with visualizations such as [[History Flow]] and [[Chromogram]] led to some of the earliest publications on the dynamics of Wikipedia, including the first scientific study of the repair of [[vandalism]].2004: Studying Cooperation and Conflict between Authors with history flow Visualizations. Fernanda B. Viégas, Martin Wattenberg, and Kushal Dave. ACM Conference on Computer-Human Interaction (CHI) Viégas is one of the founders of IBM's experimental [[Many Eyes]] website, created in 2007,Anne Eisenberg, [https://www.nytimes.com/2008/08/31/technology/31novel.html Lines and Bubbles and Bars, Oh My! New Ways to Sift Data], ''New York Times'', August 30, 2008Folha de S.Paulo, [http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/informatica/ult124u462872.shtml Many Eyes é criação de brasileira], November 1, 2008'. which seeks to make visualization technology accessible to the public. In addition to broad uptake from individuals, the technology from Many Eyes has been used by nonprofits and news outlets such as the New York Times Visualization Lab.[http://vizlab.nytimes.com/ New York Times Visualization Lab] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090214074006/http://vizlab.nytimes.com/ |date=2009-02-14 }} === Art === Viégas is also known for her artistic work, which explores the medium of visualization for explorations of emotionally charged digital data. An early example is Artifacts of the Presence Era, an interactive installation at the Boston Center for the Arts in 2003, which featured a video-based timeline of visitor interactions with the museum. She often works with Martin Wattenberg to visualize emotionally charged information. An example of these works is their piece "Web Seer", which is a visualization of Google Suggest.http://fernandaviegas.com/art.html The Fleshmap series (started in 2008) uses visualization to portray aspects of sensuality, and includes work on the web, video, and installations.Cate McQuaid, [http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2009/04/29/inside_squash_art_and_sport_confined/ Inside squash: art and sport confined], ''Boston Globe'', April 29, 2009 In 2012, she launched the [http://hint.fm/wind Wind Map project],"The Week In Ideas - On With The Wind", The Wall Street Journal, April 6, 2012. which displays continuously updated forecasts of wind patterns across the United States. == Publications == * ''Chat Circles''. Fernanda B. Viégas and Judith Donath. ACM Conference on Computer-Human Interaction (CHI), 1999 [http://alumni.media.mit.edu/~fviegas/projects/chatcircles/ Chat Circles] * ''Visualizing Conversations,'' Judith Donath, Karrie Karahalios and Fernanda B. Viégas . Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication, Vol. 4, Number 4, June 1999 {{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1083-6101.1999.tb00107.x | volume=4 | title=Visualizing Conversation | year=2006 | journal=Journal of Computer-Mediated Communication | last1 = Donath | first1 = Judith}} * ''Studying Cooperation and Conflict between Authors with history flow Visualizations.'' Fernanda B. Viégas, Martin Wattenberg, and Kushal Dave. ACM Conference on Computer-Human Interaction (CHI), 2004 [http://www.ifs.tuwien.ac.at/~silvia/wien/vu-infovis/articles/Viegas-CHI2004.pdf CHI 2004] * ''Many Eyes: A Site for Visualization at Internet Scale.'' Fernanda B. Viégas, Martin Wattenberg, Frank van Ham, Jesse Kriss, Matt McKeon. IEEE Symposium on Information Visualization, 2007 [http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/login.jsp?tp=&arnumber=4376131&url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fxpls%2Fabs_all.jsp%3Farnumber%3D4376131 IEEE Xplor] * "Luscious". Fernanda Viégas & Martin Wattenberg. Book chapter in Net Works: Case Studies in Web Art and Design. Ed. xtine burrough, Routledge 2011Net Works: Case Studies In Web Art and Design. http://www.routledge.com/books/details/9780415882224/ * "Beautiful History". Fernanda Viégas & Martin Wattenberg. Book chapter in Beautiful Visualization: Looking at Data Through the Eyes of Experts. Ed. Julie Steele, Noah Iliinsky. O'Reilly Media, 2010.Beautiful Visualization: Looking at Data Through the Eyes of Experts. http://shop.oreilly.com/product/0636920000617.do ==References== {{reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://fernandaviegas.com/index.html Fernanda B. Viégas] Personal home page for Viégas * [http://www.research.ibm.com/visual/publications.html Academic publications] listed on IBM's site. * [http://www.many-eyes.com Many Eyes] Experimental public visualization site. {{Visualization}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Viegas, Fernanda}} [[Category:1971 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Information visualization experts]] [[Category:Human–computer interaction]] [[Category:Human–computer interaction researchers]] [[Category:Contemporary artists]] [[Category:Digital artists]] [[Category:Women digital artists]] [[Category:Massachusetts Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:IBM employees]] [[Category:Brazilian women scientists]] [[Category:Brazilian scientists]] [[Category:People from Cambridge, Massachusetts]] [[Category:Google employees]] [[Category:Technology company founders]] [[Category:American company founders]] [[Category:Brazilian company founders]] [[Category:Women company founders]] [[Category:Brazilian designers]] [[Category:MIT Media Lab people]]

[[Image:Vintagefirescreen.jpg|thumb|Vintage decorative fire screen, circa 1950s]] [[Image:Modernfirescreen.jpg|thumb|Modern black metal and mesh fire screen]] A '''fire screen sheet''' began as a form of [[furniture]] that acted as a shield between the occupants of a room and the [[fireplace]], and its primary function was to reduce the discomfort of excessive heat from a log fire. Early firescreens were generally shaped as flat panels standing on attached feet, or as adjustable shield-shaped panels mounted on tripod table legs.
Firescreens in the modern home have become decorative shields of [[sheet metal]], [[glass]], or [[wire mesh]] that can be placed in front of a [[fireplace]] opening to protect the room from open flames and flying embers that may be emitted by the fire.
Fire screens were used to cover the fireplace when nothing was burning inside it, and make it look more decorative.
==Types of fire screen== The ''three-panel'' fire screen, which covers the fireplace almost completely, has two side panels angled away from the central panel. It is an effective way of providing decoration in a room.
The ''horse screen'', or ''cheval screen'' (cheval is the French word for horse) was in common use from the 18th century. It is a wide screen having two feet on each side, the arrangement of the feet giving the screen its name. Placed in front of the unused fireplace, the decorated screen improves the appearance of a room.<ref name="buff">{{citation|url=http://buffaloah.com/f/glos/f/firescreen.html |title=Fire Screen|publisher=Buffalo Architecture and History|accessdate=August 23, 2013}}</ref> Screens are decorated with [[embroidery]], [[papier maché]], painted wood or perhaps [[stained glass]]; the frame and feet might be carved.<ref name="chat">{{citation|url=http://www.antiques-art-collectibles.com/collectible/firescreen.htm|title=The History of Fire Screens|publisher=Chatelaine's Antiques|accessdate=August 23, 2013}}</ref>
The ''pole screen'' also began to appear in the 18th century. It is a smaller screen placed on a vertical pole which is mounted on a tripod; placed between a lit fire and an occupant of the room, the screen can be adjusted up or down to shield the person's face from the heat. The screen might be rectangular or a more decorous shape, and is decorated perhaps with embroidery, lacquer or paint.<ref name="buff"/><ref name="chat"/>
The ''banner'' screen is similar to a pole screen; instead of a solid screen there is a loose piece of silk or embroidery, weighted with tassels on the lower edge;<ref name="chat"/> like a banner, it is supported from the top edge by a crossbar connected to a pole.
==Some antique fire screens== <Gallery> File:Jean-Baptiste-Claude_Sené_(1748-1803),_écran_à_feu_(1787),_Museum_of_Fine_Arts,_Boston.jpg|French fire screen, 1787 File:Fire_Screen_LACMA_M.2006.51.14.jpg|Pole fire screen, Massachusetts, about 1780 File:Firescreen, about 1878-1880, Herter Brothers, New York, gilded wood, brocaded silk, embossed paper - Cleveland Museum of Art - DSC08947.JPG|Fire screen of about 1880, with [[brocaded]] silk and gilded wood </Gallery>

{{For|flow graph in computer science|Control flow graph|Rooted graph#Flow graphs|Flowchart}} A '''flow graph''' is a form of [[Digraph (mathematics)|digraph]] associated with a set of linear algebraic or differential equations:<ref name=Abrahams/><ref name=Henley2/> :"A signal flow graph is a network of nodes (or points) interconnected by directed branches, representing a set of linear algebraic equations. The nodes in a flow graph are used to represent the variables, or parameters, and the connecting branches represent the coefficients relating these variables to one another. The flow graph is associated with a number of simple rules which enable every possible solution [related to the equations] to be obtained."<ref name=Abrahams/>
Although this definition uses the terms "signal flow graph" and "flow graph" interchangeably, the term "signal flow graph" is most often used to designate the [[Mason graph|Mason signal-flow graph]], Mason being the originator of this terminology in his work on electrical networks.<ref name=Mason/><ref name=Mason2/> Likewise, some authors use the term "flow graph" to refer strictly to the [[Coates graph|Coates flow graph]].<ref name=Chen/><ref name=Hoskins/> According to Henley & Williams:<ref name="Henley2"/> :"The nomenclature is far from standardized, and...no standardization can be expected in the foreseeable future."
A designation "flow graph" that includes both the Mason graph and the Coates graph, and a variety of other forms of such graphs<ref name=Murota/> appears useful, and agrees with Abrahams and Coverley's and with Henley and Williams' approach.<ref name=Abrahams/><ref name=Henley2/>
A '''directed network''' – also known as a [[flow network]] – is a particular type of flow graph. A ''network'' is a graph with real numbers associated with each of its edges, and if the graph is a digraph, the result is a ''directed network''.<ref name=Chartrand/> A flow graph is more general than a directed network, in that the edges may be associated with ''gains, branch gains'' or ''transmittances'', or even functions of the Laplace operator ''s'', in which case they are called ''transfer functions''.<ref name=Henley2/>
There is a close relationship between graphs and matrices and between digraphs and matrices.<ref name=Harary/> "The algebraic theory of matrices can be brought to bear on graph theory to obtain results elegantly", and conversely, graph-theoretic approaches based upon flow graphs are used for the solution of linear algebraic equations.<ref name=Swamy/>
== Deriving a flow graph from equations == [[File:Signal flow graph example.png|thumb|200px|An example of a signal flow graph]] [[File:Flow graph for three linear equations.png|300px|thumb|Flow graph for three simultaneous equations. The edges incident on each node are colored differently just for emphasis.]] An example of a flow graph connected to some starting equations is presented.
The set of equations should be consistent and linearly independent. An example of such a set is:<ref name="Henley2"/>
:<math>\begin{bmatrix} 1&2&0\\ 0&1&1\\ 5&-1&-1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1\\x_2\\x_3\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}5\\5\\0\end{bmatrix} </math> Consistency and independence of the equations in the set is established because the determinant of coefficients is non-zero, so a solution can be found using [[Cramer's rule]].
Using the examples from the subsection [[Mason graph#Elements of signal flow graphs|Elements of signal flow graphs]], we construct the graph In the figure, a signal-flow graph in this case. To check that the graph does represent the equations given, go to node ''x<sub>1</sub>''. Look at the arrows incoming to this node (colored green for emphasis) and the weights attached to them. The equation for ''x<sub>1</sub>'' is satisfied by equating it to the sum of the nodes attached to the incoming arrows multiplied by the weights attached to these arrows. Likewise, the red arrows and their weights provide the equation for ''x<sub>2</sub>'', and the blue arrows for ''x<sub>3</sub>''.
Another example is the general case of three simultaneous equations with unspecified coefficients:<ref name=Deo/> :<math>\begin{bmatrix} c_{11}&c_{12}&c_{13}\\ c_{21}&c_{22}&c_{23}\\ c_{31}&c_{32}&c_{33} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1\\x_2\\x_3\end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}y_1\\y_2\\y_3\end{bmatrix} </math> To set up the flow graph, the equations are recast so each identifies a single variable by adding it to each side. For example: :<math> \left( c_{11}+1 \right) x_1+c_{12}x_2+c_{13}x_3-y_1 = x_1 \ .</math> Using the diagram and summing the incident branches into ''x<sub>1</sub>'' this equation is seen to be satisfied.
As all three variables enter these recast equations in a symmetrical fashion, the symmetry is retained in the graph by placing each variable at the corner of an equilateral triangle. Rotating the figure 120° simply permutes the indices. This construction can be extended to more variables by placing the node for each variable at the vertex of a regular polygon with as many vertices as there are variables.
Of course, to be meaningful the coefficients are restricted to values such that the equations are independent and consistent.
==See also== *[[Coates graph]] *[[Signal-flow graph]]
==Further reading== *{{cite book |title=A Combinatorial Approach to Matrix Theory and Its Applications |author=Richard A. Brualdi, Dragos Cvetkovic |isbn=9781420082234 |year=2008 |publisher=Chapman & Hall/CRC |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pwx6t8QfZU8C&pg=PA63 |chapter=Determinants |pages=63 ''ff''}} A discussion of the Coates and the Mason flow graphs.
==References== {{reflist|refs=
<ref name=Abrahams> {{cite book |title=Signal flow analysis |author=J. R. Abrahams, G. P. Coverley |chapter=Chapter 1: Elements of a flow graph |page=1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=C4ujBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA1 |isbn= 9781483180700 |year=2014 |publisher=Elsevier}} </ref>
<ref name=Chartrand> {{cite book |title=Introductory Graph Theory |author=Gary Chartrand |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3J_DAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA19&dq=%22By+a+network+we+mean+a+graph+or+digraph%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wx2wVM3XL4G2ogSepoGQBw&ved=0CCgQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22By%20a%20network%20we%20mean%20a%20graph%20or%20digraph%22&f=false |page=19 |isbn=9780486134949 |publisher=Courier Corporation |year=2012 |edition=Republication of ''Graphs as Mathematical Models'', 1977}} </ref>
<ref name=Chen> {{cite web |url=http://www.amarketplaceofideas.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/11/6016231.pdf |author=Wai-Kai Chen |title=Some applications of linear graphs |date=May 1964 |publisher=Coordinated Science Laboratory, University of Illinois, Urbana}} </ref>

[[File:Rotten apple.jpg|right|thumb|300px|This apple has decomposed to the point that it is not of a quality appealing to humans to eat]] '''Spoilage''' is the process in which [[food]] deteriorates to the point in which it is not edible to humans or its quality of edibility becomes reduced. Various external forces are responsible for the spoilage of food. Food that is capable of spoiling is referred to as [[perishable food]].
==Reasons== Harvested foods decompose from the moment they are harvested due to attacks from [[enzymes]], oxidation and [[microorganism]]s. These include [[bacteria]], [[mold]], [[yeast]], moisture, temperature and chemical reaction.
===Bacteria=== [[Bacteria]] can be responsible for the spoilage of food. When bacteria breaks down the food, [[acid]]s and other waste products are created in the process.<ref name=Tull1997 >{{citation | last=Tull | first=Anita | year=1997 | title=Food and nutrition | edition=3 | publisher=Oxford University Press | isbn=978-0-19-832766-0 | page=154 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N_s6Dn8HC8AC&pg=PA154&dq=food+spoilage&hl=en&ei=bASWTf7UBs-z8QOtz-AX&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CEgQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=food%20spoilage&f=false }}</ref> While the bacteria itself may or may not be harmful, the waste products may be unpleasant to taste or may even be harmful to one's health.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tricket|first=Jill|title=The prevention of food poisoning |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FW2gNgetJOcC&pg=PA124&dq=food+spoilage#v=onepage&q=spoil&f=false|page=8|isbn=978-0-7487-5893-7|date=2001-07-15}}</ref>
===Yeasts=== [[Yeast]]s can be responsible for the decomposition of food with a high sugar content. The same effect is useful in the production of various types of food and beverages, such as [[bread]], [[yogurt]], [[cider]], and [[alcoholic beverage]]s.<ref>{{cite book|last=Tricket|first=Jill|title=The prevention of food poisoning |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FW2gNgetJOcC&pg=PA124&dq=food+spoilage#v=onepage&q=spoil&f=false|page=9|isbn=978-0-7487-5893-7|date=2001-07-15}}</ref>
==Signs== Signs of food spoilage may include an appearance different from the food in its fresh form, such as a change in color, a change in texture, an [[unpleasant odour]], or an undesirable [[taste]]. The item may become softer than normal. If mold occurs, it is often visible externally on the item.
==Consequences== Spoilage bacteria do not normally cause "[[food poisoning]]"; typically, the microorganisms that cause [[foodborne illness]]es are odorless and flavourless, and otherwise undetectable outside the lab.<ref>Food spoilage and food pathogens, what’s the difference? October 22, 2015, Michelle Jarvie, Michigan State University [http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/food_spoilage_and_food_pathogens_whats_the_difference]</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Jeanroy|first1=Amelia|last2=Ward|first2=Karen|title=Canning & Preserving for Dummies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iJxGjFQNU2AC&pg=PA41&dq=spoiled+food&hl=en&ei=uSiRTafwNdKgtgeEwYFj&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=spoiled%20food&f=false|page=39}}</ref> Eating deteriorated food could not be considered safe due to [[mycotoxins]] or microbial wastes. Some pathogenic bacteria, such as ''[[Clostridium perfringens]]'' and ''[[Bacillus cereus]]'', are capable of causing spoilage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.foodsafety.gov/blog/2016/02/what-is-food-spoilage.html |last=Magoulas |first=Argyris |title=What is Food Spoilage? |website=Foodsafety.gov |publisher=U.S. Department of Health & Human Services |date=February 22, 2016 |accessdate=October 25, 2018}}</ref>
==Prevention== A number of methods of prevention can be used that can either totally prevent, delay, or otherwise reduce food spoilage.
A [[food rotation system]] uses the first in first out method (FIFO), which ensures that the first item purchased is the first item consumed.
[[Preservative]]s can expand the [[shelf life]] of food and can lengthen the time long enough for it to be harvested, processed, sold, and kept in the consumer's home for a reasonable length of time.
[[Refrigeration]] can increase the shelf life of certain foods and beverages, though with most items, it does not indefinitely expand it. Freezing can preserve food even longer, though even freezing has limitations.
A high-quality vacuum flask (thermos) will keep coffee, soup, and other boiling-hot foods above the danger zone (140F/58C), at which bacteria grow most rapidly,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fsis.usda.gov/wps/portal/fsis/topics/food-safety-education/get-answers/food-safety-fact-sheets/safe-food-handling/danger-zone-40-f-140-f/CT_Index |title="Danger Zone" (40 °F - 140 °F) |website=Food Safety and Inspection Service |publisher=United States Department of Agriculture |accessdate=October 25, 2018}}</ref> for over 24 hours.
[[Canned food|Canning]] of food can preserve food for a particularly long period of time, whether canned at home or commercially. Canned food is [[vacuum pack]]ed in order to keep oxygen out of the can that is needed to allow bacteria to break it down. Canning does have limitations, and does not preserve the food indefinitely.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jeanroy|first1=Amelia|last2=Ward|first2=Karen|title=Canning & Preserving for Dummies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iJxGjFQNU2AC&pg=PA41&dq=spoiled+food&hl=en&ei=uSiRTafwNdKgtgeEwYFj&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=spoiled%20food&f=false|page=41}}</ref>
[[Lactic acid fermentation]] also preserves food and prevents spoilage.
==See also== {{portal|Food}} *[[Decomposition]] *[[Food preservation]] *[[Food grading]] *[[Foodborne illness]] *[[Shelf life]]
==References== {{reflist}}

'''High definition fiber tracking''' ('''HDFT''')<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Fernandez-Miranda|first=Juan C.|last2=Pathak|first2=Sudhir|last3=Engh|first3=Johnathan|last4=Jarbo|first4=Kevin|last5=Verstynen|first5=Timothy|last6=Yeh|first6=Fang-Cheng|last7=Wang|first7=Yibao|last8=Mintz|first8=Arlan|last9=Boada|first9=Fernando|date=August 2012|title=High-definition fiber tractography of the human brain: neuroanatomical validation and neurosurgical applications|journal=Neurosurgery|volume=71|issue=2|pages=430–453|doi=10.1227/NEU.0b013e3182592faa|issn=1524-4040|pmid=22513841}}</ref> is a [[tractography]] technique where data from [[Magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]] scanners is processed through computer algorithms to reveal the detailed wiring of the brain and to pinpoint fiber tracts. Each tract contains millions of [[neuron]]al connections. HDFT is based on data acquired from diffusion spectrum imaging<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wedeen|first=V. J.|last2=Wang|first2=R. P.|last3=Schmahmann|first3=J. D.|last4=Benner|first4=T.|last5=Tseng|first5=W. Y. I.|last6=Dai|first6=G.|last7=Pandya|first7=D. N.|last8=Hagmann|first8=P.|last9=D'Arceuil|first9=H.|date=2008-07-15|title=Diffusion spectrum magnetic resonance imaging (DSI) tractography of crossing fibers|journal=NeuroImage|volume=41|issue=4|pages=1267–1277|doi=10.1016/j.neuroimage.2008.03.036|issn=1053-8119|pmid=18495497}}</ref> and processed by generalized q-sampling imaging.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yeh|first=Fang-Cheng|last2=Wedeen|first2=Van Jay|last3=Tseng|first3=Wen-Yih Isaac|date=September 2010|title=Generalized q-sampling imaging|journal=IEEE Transactions on Medical Imaging|volume=29|issue=9|pages=1626–1635|doi=10.1109/TMI.2010.2045126|issn=1558-254X|pmid=20304721}}</ref> The technique makes it possible to virtually dissect 40 major fiber tracts in the brain.<ref name=":0"/> The HDFT scan is consistent with brain anatomy unlike diffusion tensor imaging ([[Diffusion MRI|DTI]]).<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Alexander|first=Andrew L.|last2=Lee|first2=Jee Eun|last3=Lazar|first3=Mariana|last4=Field|first4=Aaron S.|date=July 2007|title=Diffusion Tensor Imaging of the Brain|journal=Neurotherapeutics : The Journal of the American Society for Experimental NeuroTherapeutics|volume=4|issue=3|pages=316–329|doi=10.1016/j.nurt.2007.05.011|issn=1933-7213|pmc=2041910|pmid=17599699}}</ref> Thus, the use of HDFT is essential in pinpointing damaged neural connections.<ref name=bunb>{{cite web|title=High Definition Fiber Tracking ' the nerve blog | Blog Archive | Boston University |url=http://sites.bu.edu/ombs/2012/10/10/high-definition-fiber-tracking/ |date=2012-10-10 |accessdate=2013-11-10 |publisher=[[Boston University]] }}</ref>
== History == Traditional DTI uses six diffusivity characteristics to model how water molecules diffuse in brain tissues and makes axonal fiber tracking possible.<ref name=":1" /> However, DTI had a major limitation in resolving axons from different tracts intersected and crossed en route to their target. In 2009, Learning Research & Development Center (LRDC) at University of Pittsburgh launched the 2009 Pittsburgh Brain Competition<ref>{{Citation|last=PBAIC2009|title=Old 2009 Pittsburgh Brain Connectivity Competition Overview|date=2009-02-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2Mv8FS3JPmM|accessdate=2018-01-31}}</ref> to invite the best research team to work on this problem.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://discovermagazine.com/2015/sept/16-broken-cables|title=Seeing the Brain's Broken Cables {{!}} DiscoverMagazine.com|work=Discover Magazine|access-date=2017-11-25}}</ref> A price of $10,000 was offered to the team that could track optic radiations, and teams from 168 countries took part in the competition. A winning team from Taiwan revealed Meyer’s loop, which no other team had successfully tracked. The technique was further developed as HDFT between the University of Pittsburgh and Carnegie Mellon University.<ref name=":0" />
== Applications == HDFT has been applied to [[traumatic brain injury]] (TBI) to identify which brain connections have been broken and which are still intact.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Shin|first=Samuel S.|last2=Pathak|first2=Sudhir|last3=Presson|first3=Nora|last4=Bird|first4=William|last5=Wagener|first5=Lauren|last6=Schneider|first6=Walter|last7=Okonkwo|first7=David O.|last8=Fernandez-Miranda|first8=Juan C.|date=2014|title=Detection of white matter injury in concussion using high-definition fiber tractography|journal=Progress in Neurological Surgery|volume=28|pages=86–93|doi=10.1159/000358767|issn=1662-3924|pmid=24923395|isbn=978-3-318-02648-1}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shin|first=Samuel S.|last2=Verstynen|first2=Timothy|last3=Pathak|first3=Sudhir|last4=Jarbo|first4=Kevin|last5=Hricik|first5=Allison J.|last6=Maserati|first6=Megan|last7=Beers|first7=Sue R.|last8=Puccio|first8=Ava M.|last9=Boada|first9=Fernando E.|date=May 2012|title=High-definition fiber tracking for assessment of neurological deficit in a case of traumatic brain injury: finding, visualizing, and interpreting small sites of damage|journal=Journal of Neurosurgery|volume=116|issue=5|pages=1062–1069|doi=10.3171/2012.1.JNS111282|issn=1933-0693|pmid=22381003}}</ref><ref name="upbs">{{cite web|url=http://www.utimes.pitt.edu/?p=20356|title=University Times ' Research Notes|date=2012-03-22|publisher=[[University of Pittsburgh]]|accessdate=2013-11-10}}</ref> HDFT allows neurosurgeons to localize fiber breaks caused by traumatic brain injuries to provide better diagnoses and prognoses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.upmc.com/Services/neurosurgery/brain/treatments/brain-mapping/Pages/high-definition-fiber-tracking.aspx|title=High Definition Fiber Tracking {{!}} UPMC {{!}} Pittsburgh, PA|website=www.upmc.com|language=en|access-date=2018-01-31}}</ref> HDFT can also be used to determine the optimal surgical approach for difficult-to-reach tumors and vascular malformations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Faraji|first=Amir H.|last2=Abhinav|first2=Kumar|last3=Jarbo|first3=Kevin|last4=Yeh|first4=Fang-Cheng|last5=Shin|first5=Samuel S.|last6=Pathak|first6=Sudhir|last7=Hirsch|first7=Barry E.|last8=Schneider|first8=Walter|last9=Fernandez-Miranda|first9=Juan C.|date=November 2015|title=Longitudinal evaluation of corticospinal tract in patients with resected brainstem cavernous malformations using high-definition fiber tractography and diffusion connectometry analysis: preliminary experience|journal=Journal of Neurosurgery|volume=123|issue=5|pages=1133–1144|doi=10.3171/2014.12.JNS142169|issn=1933-0693|pmid=26047420}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Diffusion MRI]] (DTI), uses the magnetic properties of water * [[Functional magnetic resonance imaging]] (fMRI), measures blood flow to infer neural activity
== References == <references/> == External links == *[https://sites.google.com/view/hdft-at-pitts/ HDFT lab] *[http://hdft.lrdc.pitt.edu/content/concept pitt.edu: Concept | HDFT] *[http://thejns.org/doi/abs/10.3171/2012.1.JNS111282 thejns.org: High-definition fiber tracking for assessment of neurological deficit in a case of traumatic brain injury: finding, visualizing, and interpreting small sites of damage Case report] (2012-04-30) *[http://www.upmc.com/media/NewsReleases/2012/Pages/high-definition-fiber-tracking-traumatic-brain-injury.aspx upmc.com: New High Definition Fiber Tracking Reveals Damage Caused by Traumatic Brain Injury, Pitt Team Reports] (2012-03-02) *[http://www.hdft.info/ hdft.info: HDFT for Connection Disorders] *[http://schneiderlab.lrdc.pitt.edu/content/60-minutes-20120716 pitt.edu: Featured in this “60 Minutes” feature: Apps for Autism] (2011-10-23)

FinTech Profile|date=5 July 2017}}</ref> | num_employees_year = <!-- Year of num_employees data (if known) --> | parent = | website = {{Official URL}} }} '''ID Finance''' is a [[financial technology]] company founded in 2012 by Boris Batine and Alexander Dunaev.<ref name="businessinsider">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/id-finance-profile-boris-batin-and-alexander-dunaev-2017-2?IR=T|title='We like it when things are difficult:' Meet the 29 and 33-year-old fintech founders who can set up a profitable bank in 9 months|date=9 February 2017|last=Moshinsky|first=Ben|work=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=22 December 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pymnts.com/news/alternative-financial-services/2017/russian-id-finances-emerging-markets-alt-lending-fintech-credit-fund/|title=ID Finance's Emerging Markets Alt Lending Fix {{!}} PYMNTS.com|last=|first=|date=8 August 2017|website=PYMNTS.com|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-13}}</ref> It is predominantly focused on emerging markets, which are characterized by noncompetitive financial services, limited availability of credit and high barriers to entry.<ref>{{cite web|title=Barcelona’s ID Finance raises $50 million in debt funding to expand fintech to developing countries|url=https://venturebeat.com/2017/02/16/barcelonas-id-finance-raises-50-million-in-debt-funding-to-expand-fintech-to-developing-countries/|date=16 February 2017|publisher=VentureBeat|accessdate=3 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.finextra.com/pressarticle/72792/online-lender-id-finance-bolsters-security-with-beahvioural-biometrics|title=Online lender ID Finance bolsters security with beahvioural biometrics|last=Finextra|date=2018-02-27|work=Finextra Research|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en}}</ref>
==Technology==
ID Finance's proprietary IT and risk management system collects and analyses thousands of data points in order to process loan applications in real time over the internet.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.crowdfundinsider.com/2018/02/128880-id-finance-incorporate-behavioral-biometrics-ai-based-fraud-scoring-engine/|title=ID Finance to Incorporate Behavioral Biometrics to AI-Based Fraud Scoring Engine {{!}} Crowdfund Insider|date=2018-02-27|work=Crowdfund Insider|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thebanker.com/video/v/5731451644001/techtalk-interview-with-alexander-dunaev-id-finance|title=TechTalk: Interview with Alexander Dunaev, ID Finance|last=Banker|first=The|website=www.thebanker.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-03-13}}</ref>
==Operations==
ID Finance is headquartered in Barcelona and employs 380 staff. It is providing loans to under the brand MoneyMan in Russia, Spain, Kazakhstan, Georgia, Poland, Brazil and Mexico.<ref>{{cite web|title=ID Finance raised € 10 million through the Blackmoon platform|url=http://incrussia.ru/news/id-finance-privlekla-10-mln-evro-cherez-platformu-blackmoon|date=14 March 2017|publisher=Inc Russia|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.banklesstimes.com/2017/12/08/id-finance-adds-kieran-donnelly-as-board-advisor/|title=ID Finance adds Kieran Donnelly as board advisor – Bankless Times|date=2017-12-08|work=Bankless Times|access-date=2018-03-13|language=en-US}}</ref> By having a presence in multiple markets it is better able to manage risk. It is the largest online lender in Russia and the CIS region.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.forbes.ru/finansy/igroki/240143-vremya-mikrobankirov-pochemu-biznesmen-dymov-potratil-3-mln-na-servis-moneyman|title=Время микробанкиров: почему бизнесмен Дымов вложил $3 млн в сервис Moneyman|last=Tofanyuk|first=Elena|date=5 June 2013|website=[[Forbes|Forbes Russia]]|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-03-13}}</ref> It reached profitability in 2015 and saw revenues treble to $68m in 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title='ID Finance secures $50m debt funding|url=https://www.finextra.com/pressarticle/68068/id-finance-secures-50m-debt-funding|date=16 February 2017|publisher=Finextra|accessdate=6 April 2017}}</ref> As of February 2017 the company was issuing 50,000 loans a month.<ref name="businessinsider" /> The company also plans to launch in Colombia and Peru.<ref>{{cite web|title=Menov warmer climes beckon|url=http://www.banki.ru/news/daytheme/?id=9025255|date=27 June 2016|publisher=Bankir.ru|accessdate=13 April 2017}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fintech-id-finance-bond-issues-raise-money-2017-10|title=Online lending startup ID Finance plans to raise $100 million in the next year|last=Williams-Grut|first=Oscar|date=10 October 2017|work=[[Business Insider]]|access-date=2018-03-13|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref>{{update after|2019|3|13}} According to reports, a growing number of ID Finance's customers are Gold or Platinum credit card users that are seeking more competitive rates.<ref>{{cite web|title=The owners of premium credit cards have become more likely to take microcredits|url=http://www.rbc.ru/finances/17/11/2016/582daa1d9a79470c57e40100|date=17 November 2016|publisher=RBC|accessdate=12 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.fintech.finance/01-news/ai-based-fraud-scoring-boosts-loan-approval-rate-by-50-for-id-finance/|title=AI-based Fraud Scoring Boosts Loan Approval Rate by 50% for ID [[File:Key-Relevance.jpg|thumb|right|Key Relevance Diagram]]In master [[locksmithing]], '''key relevance''' is the measurable difference between an original [[key (lock)|key]] and a copy made of that key, either from a wax impression or directly from the original, and how similar the two keys are in size and shape.<ref> {{cite encyclopedia | last = Mick | first = Friend | encyclopedia = The Encyclopaedia for Locksmiths | title = The Encyclopaedia for Locksmiths | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=086qTO_pk8EC | year = 2004 | publisher = Authors On Line, Limited | location = New York | ISBN = 0-7552-0117-5 }}</ref> It can also refer to the measurable difference between a key and the size required to fit and operate the [[keyway]] of its paired [[Lock (security device)|lock]].
No two copies of keys are exactly the same, even if they were both made from [[key blank]]s that are struck from the same [[Mold (casting)|mould]] or cut from the same duplicating/[[milling machine]] with no changes to the [[Bit (key)|bitting]] settings in between. Even under these favorable circumstances, there will be minute differences between the two key shapes, though their key relevance is extremely high.
In all machining work, there are measurable amounts of difference between the design specification<ref>[[ASTM]] engineering specification standards</ref> of an object, and its actual manufactured size. In locksmithing, the allowable tolerance<ref> {{cite book | last = Conway | first = Hugh Graham | title = Engineering Tolerances: A Study of Tolerances, Limits and Fits for Engineering Purposes, with Full Tables of All Recognized and Published Tolerance Systems | year = 1966 | edition = Third | publisher = Sir Isaac Pitman & Sons Ltd. | location = London }}</ref> is decided by the range of minute differences between a key's size and shape in comparison to the size and shape required to turn the tumblers within the lock. Key relevance is the measure of similarity between the key and the optimal size needed to fit the lock, or it is the similarity between a duplicate key and the original it is seeking to replicate.
Key relevance cannot be deduced from a [[key code]], since the key code merely refers to a central authoritative source for designed shapes and sizes of keys.
Typical modern keys require a key relevance of approximately {{convert|0.03|mm|in}} to {{convert|0.07|mm|in}} (accuracy within 0.75% to 1.75%) in order to operate.<ref> {{cite book | last = Rudman | first = Jack | title = This is Your Locksmith Passbook | year = 1985 | publisher = National Learning Corp | ISBN = 0-8373-1348-1 }}</ref>
==Other applications== "Key relevance" may also be applied to types of [[electronic lock]]s when used to refer to similarities in magnetic signatures or radio codes, though truly digital-coded radio signals do not have key relevance ratings because they must have precise unlocking codes, with no degree of difference whatsoever in order to operate.
The term has also occasionally been co-opted by broader [[mechanical engineering]] to refer to the similarity of fit between two interlocking machined parts, although "tolerance" or [[Backlash (engineering)|"backlash"]] has gained far wider adoption and acceptance in usage.
== See also == * [[Margin of error]] * [[Process capability]] * [[Specification (technical standard)|Specification]] * [[Engineering tolerance]] * [[Tolerance stacks]]

The Company is headquartered in Sao Paulo It is the leading manufacturer of packaging paper and board, corrugated boxes, [[paper sack|industrial sacks]] and timber in logs. {{Unreferenced|date=May 2009}} In [[metadata]], a '''match report''' is a report that compares two distinct [[data dictionary|data dictionaries]] and creates a list of the [[data element]]s that have been identified as [[Semantic equivalence|semantically equivalent]].
== Use of match reports ==
Match reports are critical for systems that wish to automatically exchange data such as intelligent software agents. If one computer system is requesting a report from a remote system that uses a distinct data dictionary and all of the data elements on the report manifest are included in the '''match report''' the report request can be executed.
Match reports are useful if data dictionaries use a metadata tagging system such as the [[UDEF]].
==See also== *[[Data dictionary]] *[[Data warehouse]] *[[Metadata]] *[[Semantic equivalence]] *[[Universal Data Element Framework]]
